Posts.Content: dre1045 wrote: In December 2004, at age 21, I was undergoing a routine lumpectomy for what I was told was a fibroid. When the surgeon was performing my lumpectomy, he quickly realized that what he had initially thought was a fibroid was something else.  He sent it off for testing, found out it was a border-line phyllodes tumor and eventually had to go back in and take out an additional 2 cm surrounding the tumor site.  I made it to my two-year mark with no evidence of recurrence.  Now almost four years later, I have found something in my other breast that is hauntingly familiar.  I have an appt tomorrow with the doctor and I'm very nervous.  I've been doing research and can't find anything regarding the likelihood of recurrence in the other breast.  Does this happen often?  or has this happened to anyone??  It feels a lot bigger than the other one.  The tumor they excised initially was just about an inch and a half in diameter.  I've been doing research about having a masectomy...is this something a doctor would even consider at my age??
